_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Blundell Geothermal Power Plant (hereafter referred to as Blundell) is owned and operated by PacifiCorp Energy, a division of PacifiCorp.  Blundell is located near the city of Milford, Utah within the Roosevelt Hot Springs Geothermal Area and generates electricity in an environmentally friendly manner.  The North American Industrial Classification System code for the facility is 221119, Other Electrical Power Generation.  PacifiCorp Energy operates Blundell in accordance with all applicable federal, state and local environmental and health and safety regulations and is committed to maintaining compliance with these regulations.  Blundell has implemented emergency response procedures at the facility in coordination with local emergency response agencies. 



Blundell consists of two independent geothermal power plants and associated geothermal wells.  The existing power plant referred to as Unit 1 is a single-flash steam generated power plant.  As a single-flash power plant, Unit 1 uses steam as the motive fluid for power generation and therefore, is not subject to the U.S. Environmental Protections Agency's Risk Management Plan requirements (RMP) for Chemical Accident Prevention or the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations.  The Integrated Two Level Unit Ormat Energy Converter (ITLU OEC) referred to as Unit 2 is a binary process that utilizes isopentane as the motive fluid for power generation.  The amount of isopentane in the process exceeds 10,000 pounds, which is the threshold quantity for isopentane as stated in the RMP and PSM regulations, and therefore, the RMP/PSM program covers this process.



The RMP/PSM regulations require proactive identification, evaluation and mitigation or prevention of chemical releases that could occur because of failures in processes, procedures, or equipment.  The RMP/PSM regulations define the responsibilities of employers and contractors involved in work that affects

storage and use of isopentane in the ITLU OEC.  The PHA was conducted using a hazards and operability (HAZOP) study.  A team composed of Blundell personnel with detailed knowledge of the process were directed through the HAZOP study by an RMEC Environmental, Inc. facilitator.  The objective of the study was to identify potential deviations from normal operating parameters of the process, causes for these deviations, potential consequences associated with these deviations and appropriate responses or actions to mitigate the identified hazards.  A relative risk ranking based on the probability and severity of the hazards was used to assign a hazard category to each identified deviation.  A What If? analysis, human factors evaluation and facility siting evaluation were also performed as part of the PHA to evaluate other circumstances or outside influences beyond the control of the system operators and maintenance personnel.  The PHA/HAZOP study team evaluated these influences and their possible consequences were discussed.  For each consequence, a mitigating action was presented and/or developed to address such occurrences.



All of the improvements and mitigation measures identified in the PHA that Blundell committed to accomplish have been completed or are in progress.  Any other measures identified by employees during workplace hazard surveys, or because of audit activities, will be thoroughly reviewed and considered for implementation.



At the time of this report, Blundell has complied with the RMP/PSM requirements and is committed to reviewing and updating the program periodically, as appropriate, and maintaining compliance with regulatory requirements.  This RMP/PSM plan has been developed to comply with all applicable regulations and is accessible to all interested employees/contractors at all times.  PacifiCorp Energy has been proactive in developing and implementing the RMP/PSM for Blundell, not only to comply with state and federal requirements, but also
as a commitment to workplace safety as a top priority.
